sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: From the Kremlin, a frosty response to US and NATO letters on Russia's security demands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Moscow accuses the West of not taking its views into account. The West doubles down on its commitment to sanctions against Russia. Germany and the US warn that the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline could be axed if Russia invades Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Pfizer's COVID pill gets the green light from the EU's drug watchdog, becoming the first oral antiviral treatment authorised in Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And at the Australian Open, Ash Barty becomes the first home player to reach the final in 42 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Welcome to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Welcome to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says that they've offered Russia a diplomatic solution to avoiding conflict between Moscow and Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: That's after a frosty response to those written responses from both the US and NATO to Moscow's security demands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But he said that he gave no guarantee that Ukraine will be barred from joining NATO, a contentious issue for the Kremlin. Russia's foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, said the response from the West could lead to serious discussions, but only on secondary affairs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: As for the content of the document, there is a reaction that allows us to consider the beginning of a serious conversation, but only on secondary issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But there is no positive reaction on the main issue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We consider the NATO and US letter as a whole, given that it's the reaction on draft agreements that we distributed in December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: After inter-ministerial coordination, we will report to President Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The President will take the decision on our next steps.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Germany says it will consider the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline as part of its sanctions on Russia in the event it invades Ukraine. The pipeline, which is yet to open, would provide Berlin with low-cost gas from Russia. Germany has been accused of not doing enough to support Ukraine because of its energy dealings with Moscow. But Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock says that while Germany has refused to supply weapons to Ukraine, it will continue to provide economic support to Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile Denmark has pledged to provide Ukraine with 73 million euros in support. Danish Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod met with his Ukrainian counterpart Dmytro Kuleba in Copenhagen today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Kofod said that his country is giving Kiev the support in order to promote democracy and human rights. Kuleba says that the international community must focus on hard power to deter Moscow's

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: military aggression.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We've reached the point when we really have to focus more on hard power rather than on soft power.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I'm not diminishing the underestimating the importance of soft power but this crisis is always a moment of truth and this is why we speak about weapons this is why we speak about economic sanctions this is why we speak about the consolidated position of all of us that so that President Putin sees that there are no weak links while I'm a big fan of soft power I'm afraid that this is really the time for hard power to be used.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, in Kiev for us tonight is our international correspondent Anneliese Borges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: She sat down with the former Prime Minister Arseny Yatsenyuk and she started by speaking to him about hard diplomacy and what that could mean for Kiev's response.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Take a listen to what he told her.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I still believe that the Western world can deter Putin. Otherwise, if Putin goes with the full-fledged invasion and conquers Ukraine, this would be a disaster for the European Union and for NATO. This would be a disaster for the entire free world. And this would be a success for autocratic regimes like Putin's regime and his allies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now, she also spoke to him about the response from the West, from Biden and from NATO, and whether that was a united response, but raised the issue of Germany and whether it was stepping up and giving the help that Ukraine needed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Take a listen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It's in the national interest of Germany not to have the conflict in Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Otherwise, what is to happen to German people?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They will pay more for gasoline, for electricity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Their financial system will be in a disarray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They will need to pay more as military expenditures to increase their military budget.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They will face another wave of refugees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So if I say, please, our German friends, be more committed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Show your guts. You have these guts. Help Ukraine and helping Ukraine, you're helping yourself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This is my message to our German friends.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So the 5,000 helmets simply don't cut it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Do your best not to allow Russian bullets to shoot into the Ukrainian soldiers because these helmets won't help this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, you saw our international correspondent there, Anneliese Borges, in that interview.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We can cross over to Kiev now, where she is standing by for us tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Good to see you, Anneliese.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We saw you there earlier sitting down with Arseny Yeltsin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Tell me more about what he told you in that interview.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He spoke about this fragile position of Ukraine and about the pressure Russia has been placing on this country for years now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He said that he absolutely does not trust Russia when Russia says it's not planning to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He says Russia has done that before in 2014 and may well do it again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: and may well do it again. He trusts rather the intelligence and the evidence the Americans and other Western allies have been providing, saying that Vladimir Putin is ready to attack this country. Of course, on the one hand, there is this discourse and this idea that the Western countries need to be doing much more to help. There's also still faith on diplomacy. The former prime minister is saying that he still hopes Western countries can put pressure on Russia and can deter Putin from taking the action and from actually invading or at least sending troops into Ukraine and potentially even reaching Kiev, which is something that many here talk about.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: All the while also talking about the importance of arming their military and having even more resources on that front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We've also heard about these civil defense units here in Ukraine across the country really mobilizing, getting training done. And of course, the defense ministry here in Ukraine said they're planning to arm these people. 130,000 people are enlisted in these units across the country. So what's happening here in this country is really a mixture of faith in diplomacy, or at least hope that diplomacy can still succeed, all the while preparing for the worst. Yeah, Annelies, you mentioned hope in diplomacy, but on the other side, you've also just mentioned those civil defence units, 130,000 citizens in Ukraine. That is a big step. And with that, I wonder, how do Ukrainians feel about the prospect of war looming over them? I know you and I spoke last night about the fact that they've been dealing with this for eight years. But of course, that's an escalation, I imagine. Absolutely. There is a level of uncertainty that many Ukrainians I met here in the streets of the capital Kiev today told me that they are almost accustomed to.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They have been dealing with the situation in the east of the country where separatists control parts of the Donbass region for eight years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now they have also, of course, experienced the annexation of Crimea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: experienced the annexation of Crimea. But of course the troops that have now amassed on the border change the scenario quite significantly. Many here told me well these troops have been amassing since May last year so this is also not new. But of course every now and then there is a new development and now everyone here is bracing for those military exercises Russia is planning to hold with Belarus in the next few days and weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And so that adds to the uncertainty people have been experiencing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I spoke to some Kiev residents earlier today. And this is what they told me about just how scary they feel right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Oh, sorry, I understand that we're not gonna hear from those residents right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But basically they told me that they are scared.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The situation is quite tense right now, that they hope for the best.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But one young resident here told me that if it comes to that, she and her friends were planning to travel to Europe and wait there for a while.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Of course, with the threat of war comes a whole lot other elements, including a spike in prices. Inflation has risen. So even their daily lives have become significantly more complicated in the last few weeks. Absolutely. As you say, Annelies, the knock-on effects, the ramifications here are potentially huge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much, Anneliese, for your reporting. Good to speak to you from Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, we can cross over now to Vadim Pristayko, who is the Ukrainian ambassador to the United Kingdom.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He's also the former Ukrainian foreign minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the programme, Ambassador. It is really great to have you with us. To start with, Russia said today that the prospect of war with Ukraine was, quote, unacceptable. What do you make of statements like that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you for having me here. And I actually appreciate what your correspondent is doing in Ukraine. And just wanted a short commentary that there are people who are scared and there are people who are preparing to hide and there are also people preparing to fight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: who are preparing to hide and there are also people preparing to fight. We hope that all the diplomatic efforts we were trying now to achieve will bring us results. But at the same time, we just have to prepare for war, prepare for the worst. And after seven years of war and centuries and centuries of living next to Russia and going through all the worst, we just can't have their words and trust in what they say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I mean, you mentioned that path of diplomacy and believing that it is still open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But on the other side, we also know that the British, for example, have given anti-tank missiles to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So I have to ask you, how close do you actually think an incursion could be?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It can start at any day, but hopefully it won't start again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: These rockets will actually raise the price for any invasion, and Russians also understand it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They are not endangering anybody on Russian territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There is no chance that Ukrainians will use these rockets and go and invade anything.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is purely defensive weapons, but Ukraine needs much more than that. We still have our air and we have the gaps in our maritime defence. These things we are trying to work with our partners, how we can cover. And the same with the other hand, trying to resolve the tensions, trying to understand what can be done, what compromise we can actually offer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But whilst all of that goes on, I do have to bring up a worst-case scenario and ask you, you know, what would happen if an incursion did take place into Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And also, you know, you did mention about people hiding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And I know you've also mentioned about the prospect of fleeing to Britain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I mean, just sketch out that scenario for me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: No, actually, it was not me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was your presenter who was talking from the Kiev streets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And now I'm in very peaceful London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I will be in Kiev in a couple of days, visiting Kiev with the company minister of foreign affairs of the UK to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: She wants to come and understand what is actually happening and how UK can help Ukraine even more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What I'm saying here is that we want our people to stay safe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: First, what we're doing, first agenda is to avoid any sort of war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Second, if we have to, we will fight at the same time protecting our infrastructure, protecting our civilians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All right, Vadim Pristayko, Ukrainian ambassador to the United Kingdom.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much for being with us here on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And I'll have more coming up after the break here on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Stay with us if you can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Good to have you with us. The British Prime Minister has ridiculed accusations that he authorised the evacuation of cats and dogs amid the downfall of Kabul.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson has described the suggestions that he prioritised animals over humans was quote, total rhubarb as the taliban recaptured the city in august the uk gave clearance for a charity and 150 of its animals to be evacuated this despite the fact that thousands of people were desperately trying to escape well pfizer's anti-covid pill has received the green light for use within the EU. It's called Paxlovid and the European Medicines Agency approved it but only for adults who do not need to be on oxygen and are not at risk of severe disease. The antiviral drug works by reducing the ability of the virus to replicate itself thereby curbing an infection.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: the ability of the virus to replicate itself, thereby curbing an infection. Six Japanese people are suing the Tokyo Electric Power Company, the operator of Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They claim that they developed thyroid cancer due to exposure to radiation after the facility's meltdown in 2011.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Aged between 6 and 16 at the time, they were living in the area near the nuclear reactors when a huge earthquake triggered a tsunami that caused a nuclear disaster.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Childhood thyroid cancer is an extremely rare disease to begin with.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There's a frequency of one or two cases per million people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There are 300,000 children in total in the Fukushima prefecture, so the ratio should be one case in every few years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: However, after the nuclear accident, a total of 293 cases have been recorded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We have not been able to communicate these facts to other people, as there has been discrimination against Fukushima residents since the disaster. We have spent 10 years in fear, unable to speak.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now the Australian Tennis Open is fast approaching its climax and there has been no shortage of excitement in this year's semi-finals. Ash Bharti's victory means that she becomes the first Australian to reach the final in over 40 years and in the men's doubles victory for the host nation is secured as we look ahead to an all-aussie final showdown. Well to talk all things tennis with me now, sports editor Andy Rubini.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Andy good to see you to begin with let's talk about Ash Barty because I mean it was a devastating performance seeing off Madison Keyes straight sets there I mean surely this Grand Slam is hers to you Luz. Well it was a devastating performance seeing off Madison Keyes. Straight sets there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I mean, surely this Grand Slam is hers to lose.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, it was another solid performance from Ashley Barty on home soil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The 25-year-old has looked in great shape and control and focused throughout this tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: She's used to these scorching temperatures and showed yet again against a tough opponent why she is the favourite to go all the way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Final score, they're 6-1, 6-3.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: She'll next lock horns with Daniel Collins in Saturday's final.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The American made light work of Sviatek.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And yes, she will be the underdog come Saturday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But as you said in your intro, Barty has a shot at becoming the first Australian to lift this trophy since Christine O'Neill in the late 70s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now, that's a lot of pressure for such a young player.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So I think the outcome of this final will depend on how she can cope with this pressure come Saturday.

sentences.sentence: All right, well, talking about pressure, we've got the men's semifinals still to come.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.sentence: Well, probably Daniel Medvedev.

Actually, the Russian often loses it, but regains his composure when it matters the most. We've seen it against Ozy Aliasim in the quarterfinal, came back from two sets down, saved a match point before eventually winning through in five sets. He'll next lock horns with Stefanos Tsitsipas.

The winner will either face Berrettini or Nadal with the Spaniard going for this 21st Grand Slam title.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And of course we can't forget the men's doubles final because there I mean it's a bit of a crowd pleaser we've got an all Aussie match up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

All right, Andy Ravini with the latest from the court. Thank you so much, Andy. Good to talk to you. Well, still to come on Holocaust Memorial Day, we remember one of the darkest chapters of European history. That is ahead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: That is ahead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Hello again. Glad you could join us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The International Holocaust Remembrance Day is when the millions of people systematically killed by the Nazis during the Second World War are remembered.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: A series of events in Brussels and across Europe mark the day of the liberation of the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camps in 1945.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Christopher Pitchers now reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Seventy-seven years on and still the atrocities of the Holocaust continue to shock.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: On Thursday, people all over the world marked Holocaust Remembrance Day to make sure the horrors are never forgotten.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: At the European Parliament in Brussels, survivor Margot Friedlander told Euronews that it's important to tell her story to remind people that it can always happen again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It is very, very important because only if everybody knows what it was that it can happen again is it important to be a human being? I tell them I don't care.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There is not Christian blood, Jewish blood, Muslim blood. We are all only human.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It's the same red blood. We are all the same. So isn't it important to be human and to recognize people?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The native German, who is 100 years old, was herself caught and deported to a concentration camp in the Czech Republic. She says that respect for all people is the key to combating anti-Semitism and hate speech. MARGOT KUHN, Be a human being. Respect everyone. Respect humans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: MALCOLM BRABANT, Margot, whose mother and brother were killed in the Auschwitz death camp, was speaking to MEPs in the European Parliament, where she said the memory of the Holocaust is sometimes politically abused by politicians of all colors. She finished with a warning for people to be vigilant and to not look away as they did then. Krista Pitchers, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: An incredible woman on an important day. Will we leave you with a no comment where governments throughout Europe are paying their respects to commemorate Holocaust Remembrance Day? Thanks for watching Euronews tonight. Nå er det en av de fleste stående stående i landet.
